items.text: Jackson is a very popular choice for processing JSON data in Java.
items.href: Processing JSON With Jackson - DZone Java

items.text: In the JSON Tree Model, the ObjectMapper constructs a hierarchical tree of nodes from JSON data.
items.href: Processing JSON With Jackson - DZone Java

items.text: In the constructor of the JsonNodeDemo class above, we created an ObjectMapper instance and called its readTree() method passing a File object representing the JSON document as parameter.
items.href: Processing JSON With Jackson - DZone Java

items.text: The readTree() method returns a JsonNode object that represents the hierarchical tree of employee.json.
items.href: Processing JSON With Jackson - DZone Java

items.text: In the readJsonWithJsonNode() method, we used the ObjectMapper to write the hierarchical tree to a string using the default pretty printer for indentation.
items.href: Processing JSON With Jackson - DZone Java

items.text: In Line 4, notice that we called the get() method instead of path() on the root node.
items.href: Processing JSON With Jackson - DZone Java

items.text: Both the methods perform the same functions – they return the specified node as a JsonNode object.
items.href: Processing JSON With Jackson - DZone Java

items.text: The difference is how they behave when the specified node is not present or the node doesn’t have an associated value.
items.href: Processing JSON With Jackson - DZone Java

items.text: When the node is not present or does not have a value, the get() method returns a null value, while the path() method returns a JsonNode object that represents a “missing node“.
items.href: Processing JSON With Jackson - DZone Java
